subject: Home & DIY
title: Cast Iron and the Garden Chair
description: A 60-second lesson on Cast Iron and the Garden Chair.

hook.text: Before the 1800s, outdoor furniture barely existed. Rain destroyed wood in seasons. Cast iron changed everything.

buildup.text: The Industrial Revolution made cast iron cheap for decorative use. Foundries poured molten iron into ornate molds.

discovery.text: Iron benches resisted weather, insects, and rot. Victorian parks filled with mass-produced seating for the first time.

twist.text: Cast iron's weight was its strength and curseâ€”a bench could weigh 100 kg, making rearrangement impossible.

climax.text: Aluminum replaced iron by the 1920s: same weather resistance, a third the weight. Outdoor furniture boomed.

punchline.text: Outdoor living started with unmovable benches.

quiz.question: What eventually replaced cast iron for outdoor furniture?
options: Aluminum, which offered weather resistance at less weight
